newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Greens attack Australia govt savings rebate plan.
newsitem.headline: Greens attack Australia govt savings rebate plan.

text.p: Australia's two Green senators, who could hold the balance of power needed to pass budget measures, on Tuesday criticised the government's proposed 1997/98 budget plan for a tax break on earnings on savings.
"It is funded from the government's superannuation contribution and is set up in a very regressive way," Greens senator Dee Margetts said in a statement.
"For the unemployed and the growing working poor, it will mean nothing."

Australia's Liberal-National government announced plans in its 1997/98 budget, released on Tuesday evening, to partly replace a planned tax cut known as the L-A-W tax cut with a 15 percent tax rebate on earnings from savings.
Fellow Greens senator Bob Brown said the government's savings rebate plan provided a haven for the wealthy while deserting those in need.
"The government's new savings initiative is largely a tax break for the rich," Brown said in a statement.
"On top of this, Howard seems to have abandoned clamping down on tax evasion amongst Australia's most wealthy."
He said further evidence of the government's attack on low-income earners included its budget cuts to public housing, childcare assistance and pharmaceutical benefits.
The Greens, the Australian Democrats and independent Brian Harradine can block government legislation in the upper house Senate when voting with the opposition Labor party.
Treasurer Peter Costello delivered a budget projecting an underlying deficit of A$3.85 billion in the year to June 30, 1998.
